results.title: Passenger Flight Is Diverted After Woman Threatens Flight Attendant
results.abstract: An Alaska Airlines flight from San Francisco to Chicago landed in Kansas City, Mo., after the passenger started acting erratically. She was arrested on a federal charge.

media.caption: The incident involving an unruly passenger took place aboard an Alaska Airlines flight last Friday, federal authorities said.

results.title: My Grandmother Has Alzheimer’s. Do I Need to Keep Visiting Her?
results.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the obligations we have to relatives who can no longer remember us.

results.title: Ex-Firefighter Who Threw Extinguisher at Police at Capitol Gets Prison
results.abstract: The retired firefighter, who prosecutors said struck three police officers in the head on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced to 52 months behind bars.

media.caption: The U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
media.copyright: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Medical Schools;Law Schools;Education;Graduate Schools and Students;Gerken, Heather K;US News & World Report;Columbia University;Harvard University;University of Chicago;Yale University
results.title: U.S. News Releases New Rankings for Top Law and Medical Schools, Despite a Boycott
results.abstract: After more than a dozen elite schools decided not to participate, the publication tweaked its methodology. And the ratings looked … not that different.

media.caption: Yale Law School was the first to announce it was no longer participating in the ratings. After standing alone at No. 1 last year, it shared the spot with Stanford.
media.copyright: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Social Media;Advertising and Marketing;Labor and Jobs
results.title: Is There Life After Influencing?
results.abstract: The internet personality Lee From America wanted to see what life was like as plain old Lee Tilghman. She’s not alone. But leaving behind lucrative brand partnerships and high follower counts is harder than it looks.

media.copyright: Amy Lombard for The New York Times

results.byline: By Ilyssa Daly and Jerry Mitchell
results.title: Sex Abuse, Beatings and an Untouchable Mississippi Sheriff
results.abstract: As abuse allegations in a rural jail piled up, criminal inquiries dragged on or went nowhere. No one scrutinized how the sheriff ran his jail.

media.caption: At least eight men, including four deputies and former Sheriff Terry Grassare, have been accused of sexual abuse by women held in the Noxubee County jail while Mr. Grassaree was in charge.
media.copyright: Rory Doyle for The New York Times

results.title: Should College Come With Trigger Warnings? At Cornell, It’s a ‘Hard No.’
results.abstract: When the student assembly voted to require faculty to alert students to upsetting educational materials, administrators pushed back.

media.caption: At Cornell University, the undergraduate student government wanted to require instructors to warn students about potentially traumatic course material.
media.copyright: Heather Ainsworth for The New York Times

results.title: What We Know About the Louisville, Ky., Bank Shooting
results.abstract: The gunman told at least one person that he was suicidal before the rampage that killed five people, and on Wednesday the police released 911 calls that shed more light on the harrowing attack.

media.caption: The scene at Old National Bank in downtown Louisville, Ky., on Monday, where the police said a 25-year-old man shot and killed five colleagues.

results.title: NPR to Suspend Twitter Use After ‘Government-Funded’ Label
results.abstract: The broadcaster said the label undermined its credibility “by falsely implying that we are not editorially independent.”

media.caption: NPR’s headquarters in Washington. The broadcaster was previously cited as an exception to Twitter’s guidelines on state-affiliated accounts.

results.title: The Case for Staying Married to a Spouse You Cannot Stand
results.abstract: It’s worth exploring why, so often, our culture encourages us to run from the ambivalent space between “happy” and “irreconcilable differences.”

results.adx_keywords: Comic Books and Strips;Magazines;Art;Deaths (Obituaries);Cartoons and Cartoonists;Jaffee, Al;Mad Magazine
results.title: Al Jaffee, Inventive Cartoonist at Mad Magazine, Dies at 102
results.abstract: For 55 years he created the fold-in (as opposed to, say, Playboy’s fold-out), giving readers a satirical double-take on whatever was going on in the news.

media.caption: Al Jaffee at work in 2008. In 2007, he won cartooning’s top honor, putting him in the company of Charles M. Schulz, Mort Walker, Gary Larson, Matt Groening and others.

results.adx_keywords: Skin;Content Type: Service;Neck
results.title: Why Does My Neck Look So Much Older Than My Face?
results.abstract: Nora Ephron once wrote, “Our faces are lies and our necks are the truth.” What do skin experts have to say?

results.title: Their Children Are Their Retirement Plans
results.abstract: The offspring of many East Asian immigrants are raised to support their elders in their later years. That gives a segment of Americans challenges others don’t face.

media.caption: Joy Cho, center, and her parents, upper left, and Elite Truong and her parents, upper right, are depicted in a photo illustration of intergenerational support.

results.title: Anne Perry, Crime Writer With Her Own Dark Tale, Dies at 84
results.abstract: She was well into her career as a prolific author of historical crime fiction when a murderous past was publicly revealed and dramatized in a 1994 movie.

media.caption: Anne Perry set multiple series of detective novels in 19th-century London, selling, by her count, more than 26 million copies.
media.copyright: Liz Hafalia/The San Francisco Chronicle, via Getty Images

results.abstract: It’s not just a dating thing, and it can hurt. A lot. Here are ways to cope — and move forward.

results.title: The Best Way to Comfort Someone When They’re Sad
results.abstract: A limited yet growing body of research suggests that one of the most powerful ways to support someone is also the simplest: Start a conversation.

results.title: Biden Administration Proposes Evenly Cutting Water Allotments From Colorado River
results.abstract: As the river shrinks, the Biden administration is getting ready to impose, for the first time, reductions in water supplies to states.

media.caption: Water intake towers at the Hoover Dam. Last summer, the water level at Lake Mead, created by the dam on the Colorado River, reached its lowest level ever.

results.title: An Avett Brother Meets a Founding Son: John Quincy Adams
results.abstract: Bob Crawford is part of the folk-rock band the Avett Brothers. He’s also the host of a new podcast about the sixth president.
